prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The sensitivity of CO(1-0) is estimated from the SFR of the off-nuclear starbursts (ONSBs) in Arp240. The SFR is 5 Msun/yr on average (Smith et al. 2014). Assuming Kennicutt-Schmidt law of the starbursts and the velocity width of 50 km/s, we get the peak CO flux of 430 mJy each ONSB. For the 0.5 arcsec ALMA beam, the expected peak flux is 27 mJy/beam assuming a filling factor of unity. To archive a S/N ratio of 10, we require the RMS of 3 mJy/beam with 10 km/s resolution.
We use the correlator with ~5000 km/s bandwidth and 5 km/s resolution for 12CO(1-0) line. The broad bandwidth is needed because we expect high-velocity components from molecular gas outflows.

The angular resolution should be high enough to identify and resolve the star forming clumps in ONSBs which are extended over ~1 kpc (2 arcsec). Thus we request the 0.5 arcsec resolution. The largest angular scale is estimated to be ~ 15 arcse (7.5 kpc) for these sources.

The sensitivity for CO(3-2) is estimated from the CO(1-0) sensitivity (see TJ on CO(1-0)). The flux ratio of CO(3-2) to CO(1-0) in the starburst regions of interacting galaxies VV114 is nearly 1 in the unit of K (Saito et al. 2015). Thus, assuming a filling factor of unity, the RMS of CO(3-2) is 6 mJy/beam to achieve the S/N ratio of 10 for 0.25 arcsec and 10 km/s resolution.

We use the correlator with ~1700 km/s bandwidth and ~2 km/s resolution for CO(3-2) line and dust continuum. The broad bandwidth is needed because we expect high-velocity components from molecular gas outflows.

The distribution of CO(3-2) is compact (< 3 kpc = 6 arcsec, Iono et al. 2009) in Arp 240. Thus, the high reolution of 0.25 arcsec is needed to finely resolve the individual starburst regions. The largest angular scale is estimated to be ~ 5 arcsec (= 2.5 kpc).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN, HCO+ and CS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging of HCN (4-3), HCO+(4-3) and CS(7-6)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The RMS to achieve in this science goal is estimated based on HCO+(4-3). The flux ratio of HCO+(4-3) to CO(3-2) is 0.06 in the starburst regions in interacting galaxies VV114 (Saito et al. 2015). Thus, assuming a filling factor of unity, the RMS is 390 microJy/beam to achieve the S/N ratio of 10 for 0.25 arcsec and 50 km/s resolution.

We use the correlator with ~1600 km/s bandwidth and ~2 km/s resolution for HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3) and CS(4-3) lines and dust continuum. The broad bandwidth is needed because we expect high-velocity components from molecular gas outflows.

The lines of this science goal are observed around galactic nulei of starburst galaxies. The sizes are commonly compact (< 400 pc, Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013). So, we expected that the size of dense gas is less than 1 arcsec in Arp 240. To discuss the size of dense gas, at least, the resolution of 250 arcsec is needed. The largest angular scale is estimated to be ~ 1 arcsec.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose new ALMA observations towards the off-nuclear starbursts in an interacting pair Arp 240 in CO(1-0), CO(3-2), HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), CS(7-6) and dust continuum. The off-nuclaer starbursts are unexplained by the classical scenario of the global gas inflow. This study is intended to understand the nature of the off-nuclear starbursts in interacting galaxies using molecular gas emission lines for the first time. Using multiple emission lines and dust continuum, we investigate the ISM condition, the star formation, the formation process of the off-nuclear starbursts.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency
